user.biography: The most powerful stories from human history.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
It's not just that 16th-century Hungarian Countess Elizabeth Bathory may have murdered some 650 young women, it's that she sewed their lips together, covered them with honey so bugs could eat them alive, and bathed in their blood in hopes of remaining forever young.⁠
⁠
And "The Blood Countess" is just one of the many disturbing figures in recorded history — visit the link in our profile to learn about more of history's most terrifying people.⁠
⁠
⁠
#elizabethbathory #horrifying #bloudcountess #uncoveredhistory #historystories #hungary

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Notting Hill. May be an image of 1 person, playing a musical instrument and guitar.

node.text:
On September 18, 1970, paramedics rushed into an apartment in London's Notting Hill to find Jimi Hendrix soaked in vomit and unresponsive. They rushed him to the hospital but attempts to resuscitate him failed.⁠
⁠
Visit the link in our profile to take a look back at the mysterious death of one of history's greatest guitarists.⁠
⁠
⁠
#jimihendrix #whathappenedtoday #september18th #guitarists #hendrix #todayinhistory #thisdayinhistory

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Sicily. May be an image of text that says 'DISCOVERIES Divers Just Discovered Four 2,200- Year-Old Battering Rams That The Romans Used During The Punic Wars'.

node.text:
In 241 B.C., ancient Rome defeated Carthage at the Battle of the Aegates, a naval battle off the west coast of Sicily that was so brutal it ended the First Punic War and gave Rome possession of Sicily for good. Now, archaeologists have more clues as to just how the Roman Navy managed to sink more than 50 Carthaginian ships in a single day.⁠
⁠
Divers have recovered four battering rams that were affixed to the front of Roman ships and used in head-on collisions to decimate the hulls of opposing ships. Using three blades each, these battering rams could turn the wood of others' ships to splinters — learn more about this discovery by visiting the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
#historynews #punicwars #ancienthistory #ancientrome #navalwarfare #fascinating

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 18, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 2 people and people standing.

node.text:
When Mr. Rogers got a call from the White House saying he would receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom on July 9, 2002, he said, "Oh, I'm so sorry, I won't be able to make it. That's our 50th wedding anniversary."⁠
⁠
While he may have been a dedicated host to his beloved children's program Mister Rogers' Neighborhood for 31 seasons, his role as Joanne Rogers husband was his most treasured. Read more about Joanne Rogers, the beloved wife of Fred Rogers, by following the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
⁠
#fredrogers #joannerogers #misterrogers #misterrogersneighborhood #lovestories

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Little Rock Central High School. May be an image of 4 people and people standing.

node.text:
On the first day of racial integration at Little Rock Central School in 1957, Elizabeth Eckford was one of the first nine Black students to ever attend classes there. While she may have expected some pushback, nothing could have prepared her for the angry mob that greeted her on her first day.⁠
⁠
Not only did they scream slurs and obscenities at her, they also called for her to be lynched. Even worse, Arkansas National Guardsmen stopped her at the door so she couldn't get inside. It would take weeks before she could even attend a single class — where she would again be subjected to continued harassment.⁠
⁠
See more disturbing photos of the anti-civil rights movement by visiting the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
⁠
#civilrights #blackhistory #littlerock #littlerockcentral #elizabetheckford #segregation #integration #historyphotos

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 17, 2021. May be an image of monument and text that says '2018YO 1 100 DISCOVERIES Archaeologists Find Traces Of9,000- Year-Old Beer Buried Alongside Two Skeletons In China'.

node.text:
Researchers digging in southern China recently unearthed some of the most unique pottery ever found on Earth. These 9,000-year-old drinking vessels are believed to be "the earliest known painted pottery in the world." But what might be even more astounding is what researchers found inside: traces of 9,000-year-old beer. According to experts, "This ancient beer though would not have been like the IPA that we have today. Instead, it was likely a slightly fermented and sweet beverage, which was probably cloudy in color."⁠
⁠
Learn more about this one-of-a-kind discovery by visiting the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
#ancienthistory #ancientchina #chinesehistory #discoveries #beer #getlit

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 17, 2021. May be an image of 4 people, child, people standing and indoor.

node.text:
America's favorite child star Macaulay Culkin has since retired from acting, but his career might have taken a different turn were it not for his abusive parents. Born into a Roman Catholic family of eight kids living in near-poverty in 1980s New York, Macaulay's charm became the family's saving grace.⁠
⁠
But his father Kit, an aggressive alcoholic, managed that star-studded career into the ground. By 1994, Kit Culkin was the highest-paid manager in Hollywood, handling his son's $17 million estate. Behind the scenes though, Culkin regularly beat his children, threatened Macaulay before his performances, and once even caused a scene at his 1991 SNL appearance when he demanded none of the actors use cue cards. Fed up, Macaulay filed for emancipation from his parents when he was just 15 years old — and won.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our profile to learn more about how Macaulay Culkin's father exploited him and the stories of eight more celebrities whose parents nearly torpedoed their careers.⁠
⁠
⁠
#macaulayculkin #theculkins #hollywood #childactors #childstar

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 17, 2021. May be an image of 6 people, people sitting and people standing.

node.text:
As 1960s America became awash with free-spirited hippies, across the pond young people enjoyed their own "Summer of Love" as Mods with coiffed cuts and Vespa scooters took over the city streets. Espousing gender equality and independence, the Mods attended fast-paced jazz shows unchaperoned and stretched their budgets to afford unisex high-heels. Explore the stylish Mod movement of 1960s Britain by visiting the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
#uk #englishhistory #themods #1960s #counterculture #europe

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Bronx, New York. May be an image of 10 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
"There were gangs literally at every corner. The violence was everywhere. You could feel the tension in the air, you can see the fights across the street, you can hear the shouts in the night time."⁠
⁠
No borough felt the consequences of "white flight" like the Bronx did in the 1970s. Once solidly middle-class, the Bronx lost 30 percent of its population in just a decade and those who fled took most of the borough's wealth with them. See more of the decade-long demise of the Bronx by following the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
⁠
#bronx #southbronx #1970s #whiteflight

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered in Antietam National Battlefield. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
Bodies of Confederate artillerymen near Sharpsburg, Maryland after the Battle of Antietam on September 17, 1862 — the single deadliest day in U.S. military history.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio for more powerful colorized images of the American Civil War like you've never seen before.⁠
⁠
⁠
⁠
⁠
#antietam #sharpsburg #historyincolor #todayinhistory #whathappenedtoday #usmilitary #militaryhistory

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 16, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
In 1865, Andrew Johnson became president of the United States — at one of the most divisive moments in the country's history. As Abraham Lincoln's vice president, Johnson took office after Lincoln's assassination and assumed the responsibility of bringing the South back into the Union after the Civil War. ⁠
⁠
But in the eyes of Republicans in Congress, Johnson was going too easy on the secessionists. He favored amnesty for virtually all Confederates and was not particularly devoted to giving formerly enslaved people voting rights. Johnson also gave a notorious speech in 1866, during which he attacked abolitionists and even accused them of plotting his assassination. Then, he vetoed the Civil Rights Act of 1866, which forced Congress's hand in overriding him. But it wasn't until 1867 that he finally took things too far. ⁠
⁠
Johnson had long been frustrated with Lincoln's Secretary of War, the Radical Republican Edwin Stanton. So Stanton's political allies in Congress tried to protect him by passing a bill that required the president to get approval from the Senate before dismissing certain cabinet members. But Johnson defied the law and sacked Stanton, leading to his impeachment in 1868. Ultimately, Johnson was narrowly acquitted — by just one vote. It would be over 100 years before the House impeached another president. ⁠
⁠
Discover the stories behind all of the U.S. presidential impeachments by visiting the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
#andrewjohnson #politics #ushistory #impeachment #uspresidents

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by History Uncovered on September 16, 2021. May be an illustration.

node.text:
Often described as the "original Spider-Man," Anansi is a spider god and a charming trickster of West African lore. While his story first emerged in Ghana, his influence has spread far and wide throughout the centuries — largely because of the transatlantic slave trade. ⁠
⁠
When Africans were brought to the Americas, they often maintained their cherished oral traditions and passed them on to the next generation so that they wouldn't fade away. Before long, new stories about Anansi had emerged in the Caribbean and the American South, where he took on a new significance as a symbol of resistance. And centuries later, the spider god would inspire countless beloved characters in children's books, television shows, and comics — including Spider-Man.⁠
⁠
Go inside the fascinating history of Anansi by clicking the link in our profile.⁠
⁠
⁠
#ghana #anansi #mythology #interesting #lore #africanhistory
